review.title: Identifying Independence in Relational Models
review.abstract: The rules of d-separation provide a framework for deriving conditional independence facts from model structure. However, this theory only applies to simple directed graphical models. We introduce relational d-separation, a theory for deriving conditional independence in relational models. We provide a sound, complete, and computationally efficient method for relational d-separation, and we present empirical results that demonstrate effectiveness.

metadata.title: Identifying Independence in Relational Models

sections.text: The rules of d-separation provide the framework for deriving conditional independence factors from the model structure. However, this theory applies only to simple oriented graphical models. We present the relational d-separation, a theory for deriving conditional independence in relational models. We provide a solid, complete and computationally efficient method for relational d-separation and present empirical results that prove its effectiveness.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The rules of d separation are the basis for the algorithmic derivation of conditional independence facts implied by the structure of a steered graphic model (Geiger et al., 1990). Precise reasoning on such conditional independence facts is the basis for constraint-based algorithms, such as PC, FCI, and MMHC, which are commonly used to learn the structure of Bayesian networks (Spirtes et al., 2000; Tsamardinos et al., 2006).Bayesian networks assume that data instances are independent and identically distributed, but many real systems are characterized by interaction with heterogeneous units. In the last 15 years, researchers have developed more expressive classes of directed graphic models, such as probability relational models (PRMs), which remove this assumption (Getoor and Taskar, 2007).Many practical applications have benefited from learning and reasoning with these models. Examples include the analysis of gene-regulation interactions (Segal, ERylar, 2001, Taswkar, etc.).

sections.heading: 5 EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: In addition to the theoretical results, we present a series of experiments with synthetic data. We implemented the relational d-separation as well as random generators for schemes, models and queries.

sections.heading: 5.1 ABSTRACT GROUND GRAPH SIZE
sections.text: Therefore, it is important to quantify how large an AGG can be (i.e., how many nodes and edges are created) and determine which factors affect its size. We conducted 500 studies for each combination of entities (1-4), relationships (from one less than the number of entities to paired relationships with randomly selected cardinalities), attributes for each entity and relationship (Pois (1.0) + 1), and dependencies (1-10). We discovered the following facts: (1) As the number of entities, relationships, attributes, and many cardinalities increases, the AGG grows in terms of both nodes and edges; (2) as the number of dependencies in the model increases, the number of entities increases, but the number of nodes, attributes, and many cardinalities increases in terms of nodes and edges.

sections.heading: 5.2 MINIMAL SEPARATING SET SIZE
sections.text: Fortunately, the relational d separation produces minimal separators that are empirically observed as small. We performed 100 experiments for each setting of the number of units (1-4), relationships (one less than the number of units with randomly selected cardinalities), total number of attributes fixed at 10, and dependencies (1-10). For each relational model, we identified a minimum separator for up to 100 randomly selected pairs of conditional relational variables. To find a minimal separator between relational variables X and Y, we modified algorithm 4 developed by Tian et al. (1998) by starting with all the parents of X and Y, supplemented by the number of nodes they subsume in the AGG.

sections.heading: 5.3 EMPIRICAL VALIDITY
sections.text: As a practical demonstration, we examine how the expectations of the relational d separation theory correspond to the results of statistical tests on actual data. We parameterise relational models using additive linear equations, average aggregation for relational variables, and evenly distributed error terms. If Y has no parents, we use linear regression and test the coefficient of Avg (X) in the equation Y х β0 + β1avg (X) + · · + βiavg (Zi) for each Zi-Zi cell. In 100 studies, we randomly generate a scheme and model for different numbers of entities (1-4), relationships (one less than the number of entities), and attributes of entities as quantity.

sections.heading: 6 SUMMARY AND DIRECTIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we extend the theory of d-separation to models of relational data. We formally define d-separation and offer a solid, complete, and computationally efficient approach to deriving conditional independence facts from relational models. We also provide an empirical assessment of relational d-separation using synthetic data. The results of this paper imply errors in the design and analysis of some real-world studies. If researchers of social or economic systems choose inappropriate data and models, their analyses may omit important classes of dependencies (i.e., they may conclude that causal dependence exists where conditional independence has not been recognized). Our work shows that researchers should think carefully about how to present their domains in order to argue accurately about conditional independence. Our experiments also suggest that more accurate tests of conditional independence for relational data need to be developed, especially those that can deal with the interaction of relational structure and aggregation.
